entry.et: Middle English benethe, from Old English beneothan, from be- + neothan below; akin to Old English nithera nether nether

def.dt: :in or to a lower position :below the mountains and the towns beneath
:in or to a lower position than :below beneath the surface
:directly under the ground beneath her feet
:at the foot of a camp beneath a hill
:not suitable to the rank of :unworthy of beneath his dignity
:under the control, pressure, or influence of the chair sagged beneath his weight
:concealed by :under the guise of a warm heart beneath a gruff manner
